awd_titl_txt: Quantal Heating in Electron Systems with Discrete Spectra
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT:
Conversion of electrical energy into heat, so called Joule heating, is one of the major physical processes affecting the modern economy. Due to Joule heating the overall electrical energy losses between power plants and consumers is in the range between 8 and 15%. A reduction of such enormous losses would be highly beneficial for society. Recently the principal investigator team has discovered that quantum properties of matter substantially affect Joule heating, that leads to a strong reduction of the energy losses. One of the main goals of this project is to reveal the mechanisms of the electrical energy dissipation in quantum electrical conductors. The proposed study of the temporal evolution of Joule heating may help realize this goal. The research results are of paramount importance for the design of novel energy-lossless electrical conductors utilizing the quantum properties of matter. The research is accomplished via direct participation of students of the City College of New York, which is a federally recognized minority serving institution.  The activity has great impact on these students, providing training and education in advanced areas of quantum physics and material science.

TECHNICAL ABSTRACT:
Joule heating is a remarkable physical phenomenon, which transforms electric energy into heat. Recently it was shown that the quantum properties of matter significantly affect this heating, giving rise to a thermal stratification (quantization) of the electron distribution in the energy space. This effect, called quantal heating, does not exist in classical electron systems. In contrast to classical Joule heating, quantal heating leads to outstanding nonlinear transport properties of highly mobile 2D electrons, driving them into exotic nonlinear states in which voltage does not depend on current and vice versa. This project is the original study of the dynamics of quantal heating and the exotic nonlinear states in highly mobile 2D electron systems placed in quantizing magnetic fields. The research includes investigations of fundamental mechanisms of the nonlinear response: spectral diffusion, spatial electron redistribution and inelastic electron relaxation in different regimes including the dc-driven exotic nonlinear states of 2D electrons and Quantum Hall Effect. Investigations of nonlinear electron transport at half-integer filling factors are focused on the search for quantal heating and nonlinear states of composite fermions in response to dc bias. The project reveals the important role of quantum effects in the transfer of electric energy into heat. The research is accomplished via direct participation of students of the City College of New York, which is a federally recognized minority serving institution.  The activity has great impact on these students, providing training and education in advanced areas of quantum physics and material science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Joule heating is a remarkable physical effect which transforms electric energy into heat. This phenomenon has significant impact on our everyday life. Many useful devices such as different electrical heaters and/or light bulbs are based on Joule heating. Other devices such as microwave ovens use Joule heating to cook food. In fact, all electrical devices around us produce Joule heat.  The conversion of electrical energy into heat is one of the major physical processes affecting the modern global economy. Due to Joule heating the overall electrical energy losses between power plants and consumers are in the range between 8 and 15%. A reduction of such enormous losses would be highly beneficial for the society. Recently the principal investigator team has discovered that quantum properties of matter substantially affect Joule heating, that leads to a strong reduction of Joule energy dissipation. The quantum properties of Joule heating are the focus of the project. The project has revealed and studied the most essential physical parameters controlling the phenomenon.

It is known that electrons are responsible for Joule heating.  As recognized by the PI team, the quantum nature of electrons plays very important role in the transferring electric energy into heat in conductors with a quantized electron spectrum.  The quantization of the electron motion leads to a formation of energy levels (bands) separated by energy intervals forbidden for the electrons - called also energy gaps. One of the most vital electron properties, which determined the width of the formed electron bands is the quantum electron lifetime. Due to lattice imperfections as well as the electron-electron scattering, an electron transfers from one quantum state to another one, living a finite time in particular quantum state. An average of this time is the quantum electron lifetime.   It turns out that this electron lifetime affects significantly Joule quantal heating. In electron systems with a long quantum lifetime Joule heating is substantially reduced. Such systems are found to dissipate considerably smaller electrical energy, which is important for applications.  

The project has developed novel methods for comprehensive studies of the electron quantum lifetime.   The methods are based on an analysis of the quantum transport of electrons in quantizing magnetic fields and yield both the temperature and energy dependences of the quantum electron lifetime. In the project the temperature and energy dependences of the quantum lifetime are obtained and studied. Good agreement is established between the experiments and theory. The energy dependence of the quantum lifetime indicates that the electron lifetime increases at a small energy that leads to considerable enhancement of the quantum mechanical response of studied systems. The research results facilitate the design and development of novel energy-lossless electrical conductors, utilizing the quantum properties of matter.

The obtained results are important for the control and reduction of Joule quantal heating but have much broader impacts.  The findings pave a way to investigate the energy and temperature dependences of the quantum lifetime in a broad range of electron systems, in which the interaction between charged carriers plays an essential role. Such correlated electron systems are of paramount importance for modern applications.  The quantum computing represents another area, which benefits from the project findings.  A long quantum lifetime is required for the quantum qubits. The longer quantum lifetime the more reliable quantum computations are expected. The developed methods are applicable to study the quantum coherence time (quantum lifetime) of spin-qubits in semiconductor hosts.

The research was accomplished via direct participation and support of graduate and undergraduate students of the City College of New York, which is a federally recognized minority serving institution and New York University.  Two CCNY graduate students: Jesse Kanter and Sara Abedi, have successfully defended their PhD dissertations based on the NSF supported research.  The activity has great impact on all students participated in the project,  providing training and education in advanced areas of the quantum physics and material science.
